Three students brought weapons, including two firearms, to school this year, and there were suppose to be random checks by metal detectors, but that never happened. One of the things that contributes to uneven teaching is that after the sixth grade, students are tracked into 'top' classes or regular classes. The top classes have the highest performing, and often better behaved students. Almost all of the major discipline problem students end up in the other classes, making them very difficult to teach. Though the school offers regents science classes, no students passed last year and only one passed this year.

Principal Yvette Beasley received a 2009 Cahn fellowship, a 15-month program at Teachers College designed to recognize outstanding principals. Cahn fellows attend workshops at Teachers College and mentor an aspiring principal while continuing to serve as principal at their school.

Stephanie, an 8th-grader who has attended the school since Sept. 2003, writes: "IS 129 has a good, structured way of teaching that has prepared me for high school. Right now I'm taking Regents classes for earth science, so I won't have to take them next year ... The teachers really care how a student does in their education and will try their hardest to make a child reach his or her potential if the child is willing to try." She adds: "IS 129 has a lot of interesting activities such as dances and more. The school is divided into two academies, science and law. I think these academies give kids something to represent and respect."
Tiffany, a former student, wants to thank the people at IS 129 for "getting [her] into high school," where she is "doing well."

"The staff here really cares," said the school's guidance counselor. "Kids hang out with grown-ups at lunch and high school students come back to visit. It's kid friendly."

A student writes that the school is "bad" and needs "more [staff members] and better lunch."
The Department of Education has announced that PS 134 will have a Spanish transitional bilingual education program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.

PS 134 is a "proficient" school according to the Department of Education's quality review report, which says that it "lives up its principles of being a caring community committed to raising students' standards and aspirations," but it "has yet to fully integrate its assessments and analysis into its systems for planning and monitoring" student progress.
"This school has great after-school opportunities," the PTA president said. "They give the kids a chance to do more than homework and TV."

A former teacher writes: "Great administration that supports teachers and provides curriculum in order to help students succeed 3 social workers are dedicated to support the students on a daily basis.
--Dedicated Literacy Coaches
--Dedicated math coach
--2 science clusters
--2 tech teachers, one room with state of the art macs
--Smartboards in every classroom
--Dance cluster with 2 major shows a year (Holiday and Spring)
--PE cluster
--SS Cluster
--2 full day pre-k classes
-Recipient of many Grant programs, tech, healthy fresh fruits for the students daily
--Strong teaching staff
--no dedicated art room or science lab
-older building
--most gen ed classes have max of 32 students
--for the most part each grade has ICT and bi-lingual classes
--12:1:1 self-contained bridge classes 
-3 APs - 1 has been added for Fall 2013
--students play at park across the street after lunch, the street is closed off to keep students safe
--wonderful school aides that have been there a long time and are hard workers
--Many after school and weekend programs to support students and parents
--Librarian has many parent workshops
--ESL workshops for parents

A former teacher writes: "PS 150 in the Bronx is a good place with an amazing administration that supports the teachers and helps the students." While "the students are very high needs and have issues," the teacher says the school has "three social workers dedicated to helping students resolve issues on a daily basis."

PS 150 is a "proficient" school with some "well-developed" features, according to the Department of Education's quality review report, which says the school needs to "raise the performance in English language arts to that achieved in mathematics."

Citing the importance of ongoing teacher training, Principal Edwin Irizarry states, "Good training equals good teachers. . . . if we can make our teachers more knowledgeable, they feel good about themselves and that knowledge goes out to the kids."

IS 190 students had their original song performed by the cast member of "Mathilda" at a special event hosted by the show's producers, the Royal Shakespeare Company. Read more here.

I.S. 190 special ed teacher Maribeth Whitehouse is one of the top-rated teachers in the city. But, she explains on GothamSchools, she doesn't put stock in the teacher data reports. She says the true value of teaching is the relationships she builds with her students. Read ten reasons she teaches here: http://whyiteach.learningmatters.tv/?p=212
The state released its list of persistently dangerous schools, including 9 NYC schools. Read more: Now it’s beatin', riotin' & 'rithmetic.

unreported abuse, favoritism by staff above teachers, teachers fear for their positions, students are hugged and then screamed at. classes are over crowded making it difficult to control students.  A dismissive attitude to students in need of services.
IS 190 is a "proficient school" according to the New York City Department of Education's quality review report.

A parent writes that she is concerned about overcrowding and lack of resources at the school, which serves "grades six through eight with only one floor for these children." She describes a "lack of school resources and supplies such as computer rooms, lockers, recreational workshops etc. My daughter has had to pay for this with her school supplies being stolen including text books, teachers inability to control classroom size behavior and attention needs and disadvantage of being exposed to such things as workshops. My daughter's grades are suffering and this is my major concern."
PS 195 is a "proficient school with well-developed features," according to the Department of Education's quality review report.

"By having used different programs and been in the Chancellor's District we understand the best instructional practices," said Principal Andrew Kavanagh. "We understand what good literacy instruction is and see the necessity to comprehend word problems to acquire good math skills."
The Department of Education has announced that PS 196 will have a Spanish transitional bilingual education program from the start of the 2016-2017 school year.

PS 211 has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. PS 211's partner is Children's Aid Society. Read more about the program here and see the full list of schools, their community partners and their proposed services here.

Chancellor Walcott visited PS 211 to observe the Summer Quest program being hosted at the school. The program runs for a full day and combines a schedule of academic classes with hands-on projects, field trips, and a camp-like atmosphere. Read more here.

I attended CS 211 when it was located on Lafontaine Avenue. It was in an old post office building and class room grades were combined. All classrooms were all open, just separated by partitions. The what to let any readers know, this is the best school in all of the Bronx. Ms. Kay, Mr Silen, Ms Lacen, Mrs Carrasquillo, Ms Mathews, Ms Roqriques, Ms burgos, Ms. Steward, Mr. Guevarra, Mr Martinez, were some of the most dedicated teachers I ever knew. The life lessons they taught me were priceless, there aren't words that can describe the value. Not only were they teachers they were role models. I remember Ms kays words to us the first day of school. "If you come to my class un prepared it shows a lack of respect " She did not tolerate disrespect or lack of effort. Ms. Kay and Ms. Lacen are one of the best teachers around. CS 211 is a school of excellence.

"I like it, 'cause I like to learn a lot, and the teachers are nice," said one student.

"C.S. 211 takes the name the 'bilingual school' for a reason. Many of the activities, programs and most of the curriculum are based on a truly bilingual and multicultural standpoint. The school celebrates the two main languages that are spoken in the school, English and Spanish, and incorporates various aspects from many of the Spanish-speaking countries represented by its student body. The math curriculum also prepares students for college-prep math," writes Jay Santiago, a former student who is now at New York University.
A student writes that since students are required to wear uniforms, there should be a special uniform for the wintertime, because "students are complaining of the cold."

Laurer, a student, writes that CS 211 is "the best [junior high school] and that she wishes to thank all her teachers for helping her learn English and make academic progress. She writes: "I know that my English is not so good but I know that I'm going to learn more before the year will finish."

Christina Pantojas, a 1998 graduate, writes: "211 was and still is my second home, I was a student there since Pre-k. It is a wonderful school. The teachers and staff are like family, and are always willing to help each other in any way possible. I would recommend this school to all parents looking for a school to place their child."

"I come from a large family and majority of my siblings have attended and graduated with honors from 211x," writes a parent. "Now in keeping the tradition going, we have enrolled our children in 211x. My fellow siblings and I love our school. We have learned so much- from respect and loyalty to achieving and striving for our beliefs. We come from the original 211x with no walls just chalkboards and closets dividing the classroom, and we still achieved and graduated with honors and great standings.. and it's all because of the teachers and staff who show great appreciation and care for each student."
"We're small and there's a family component to the school," said the parent coordinator, who was a family assistant at the school for 17 years.
"The principal is 'old school.' She wants things a certain way," said a longtime teacher. "Scores are everything."
the school will no longer be within 3 years
The Daily News article referenced below was found to be baseless upon investigation by N Y State and the NYC Dept of Education.

About 75 students at P.S. 212 who spoke little English were denied state mandated language classes for almost seven months,until March of 2010 according to the Daily News. An additional 50 students who speak English but are not fluent also did not receive the extra help.
"I love the school and the staff," says a parent of a 7th grade student, "They work with you; if there's a problem, they help. I tell other parents to apply for PS 212 because it's one of the best."
One 8th grade student who transferred from another school says he prefers PS 212 because "the teachers and students have a bond, plus there's not as much fighting here."

PS 214 is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.

P.S. 214 is going to offer a gifted and talented program for students entering the third grade, but will not be assessing students with tests as the other programs in the city do. Read more here.

Chancellor Carmen Fariña announced 73 schools selected to join the Learning Partners Program, an innovative and collaborative initiative that brings schools together to share practices to improve learning in the classroom and raise student outcomes. Through the program, one host school with strong practices in a particular focus area will support two partner schools seeking to strengthen their own practices in that area. PS 214 was chosen to host P.S. 109 Sedgwick and P.S. 143 Louis Armstrong. Read more here.

National Dance Institute (NDI), a program founded by Jacques d'Amboise, offers dance instruction to all 5th graders, an NDI spokesman said.

Mohanhall writes of a teacher who would remain at school long after the end of the school day to tutor students and help kids facing difficulties at home.
A parent writes that students at the school are working hard in preparation for their performance of the musical Once on this Island.

School of Performing Arts has been removed from the State Education Department's list of struggling schools and no longer faces possible receivership. Politico New York reports.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.

School of Performing Arts landed on the state Education Department’s list of “persistently dangerous schools" in 2014. Schools on the list have a high number of violent or disruptive incidents. Read more here.

The School of the Performing Arts is one of seven Bronx schools that will work with the The Stella Adler Studio of Acting to provide students with an acting school experience for the next three years. Through 24 weeks of coursework, students will receive ensemble, voice, movement, and improvisation lessons in their school. Read more here.
A guidance counselor at IS 217 writes about her students' high school matches for SchoolBook.
This school the wave, this is coming from the most known person in that school Hector A. Perez
"I currently go to IS 217," writes an 8th grader. "I think it's a great school." He notes that the school no longer has a 5th grade.

"This is a school where all of the teachers and staff make you feel at home," writes Lyann V., a student. "They worry about the way you act in school and make you feel at home. They have metal detectors in the school. The line for the metal detectors can be long but it's for the best of it. I'm glad to be a graduate at IS 217."

The parent coordinator says she wants parents to feel comfortable stopping by the school and asking questions. "Parents think they need an appointment to come into the school," she said. "This is a school. It isn't a doctor's office."
Mott Hall V is one of 15 NYC schools to receive a $10,000 grant to promote spaces to increase mental and physical health inside the school building, News12 Brooklyn reports.

I AM A PARENT OF A CHILD WHO ATTENDS MOTTHALLV. I must say is one of the best schools.. teacher staff principal they are all about helping there students ..The love and support they show its unconditional..hands down MOTTHALLV. IS A VERY GOOD SCHOOL.....
I love many of the teachers

The New York Post named Mott Hall V as a NYC school with a high percentage of student work made up in credit-recovery programs. Forty-six percent of credits came from makeup work in the 2011-2012 school year.
Many of the teachers affected by the last-in first-out layoff process in NYC are young, energetic and idealistic.  Read the story: New to Teaching, Idealistic, at Risk for Layoff.
I believe that MHV is a great school that teaches students responsibility, and the defines the term of Math, Science and Technology.

A grandmother writes to tell us she is "very pleased with Mott Hall V." At a recent Parents' Night there were "a few bumps but nothing major. I liked all of my grandson's teachers. They were so informative and respectful. I really believe that the teachers want to teach and they want the kids to be successful. I like the way the school is set up. All the kids must wear uniforms and what I love the most is that they must wear shoes." She notes that after a month at the school, her grandson comes home and is "doing his homework without a fuss. As of this day I give the school 3 stars and I hope there are more to come."
"I like it because the teachers push us to do more work," a student said.
"The school helps kids," a student said. "In my old school, the teachers didn't teach. Here, they teach."
"When they make the projects and the work, they make it fun," one student said.

Bronx Latin science teacher Aida Rosenbaum was named one of seven winners of the 11th Annual Sloan Awards for Excellence in Teaching Science and Mathematics in New York City Public High Schools, Patch reports.

In the Department of Education’s November 2014 Principal Notes, Chancellor Fariña acknowledged Bronx Latin High School Principal Annette Fiorentino for creating the conditions for students to beat the odds. Fariña commended the school's 89 percent graduation rate and 95 percent attendance rate for an unscreened school with 22 percent of students with special needs.

I have been working here 7 years, and love teaching here. Contrary to the review, we do offer Latin to our middle schoolers. For middle school students we offer our advanced 8th graders the Algebra Regents, Living Environment Regents, and Spanish regents. In the high school we have students taking AP classes and College Now classes at Lehman college, and have been ranked #27 in NYC. I am proud to have worked here so long, and know it will be bittersweet to see the students I started teaching in 6th grade graduate this year as 12th graders and go off to college. However I know we have prepared them well.

In September, 2013 Bronx Latin was ranked among the Top 50 High Schools in New York City at #27 by The Post.  Congratulations Bronx Latin!
http://nypost.com/2013/09/15/top-50-public-schools-in-nyc/
This is a bootleg Brooklyn Latin.

Actually, our founding principal was trying to base it off of the Boston Latin school model, which is the same as the Brooklyn Latin seemed to adopt when that school was founded. And we were founded in 2004, whereas Brooklyn Latin was founded in 2006. We have nothing to do with Brooklyn Latin, but we did try to take some of the Boston Latin model (like Brooklyn Latin did) as far as having uniforms, Socratic Seminars, offering Latin to our students, etc.
looks like a great school
looks like a great school
It's a great school. It really did prepare me for college

Bronx Latin was the subject of a profile in the New York Times on Nov. 29, 2006. The profile describes lessons in which students are engaged in the study of the ancient language and teachers who are dedicated to using Latin to turn students on to academics and study skills in general.
"I feel lucky to be working here, " states one Bronx Latin teacher who is new to the profession, "We are able to give the students a lot of individual attention and I think the kids are happy, too."
"I like the fact that we will be role models to the new kids who come in next year," said one student. "Also we get the help we need and everybody is like a family."

Frederick Douglass Academy V. Middle School is among 40 middle schools selected for an extended learning day pilot with 2.5 more learning hours in the school day for all students, and daily literacy tutoring for high needs students. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.
"Parent-teacher night was flooded. That makes a big difference in how students perform in school," says Principal Deborah Cimini.

Fannie Lou Hamer is on a list of 50 schools that will participate in the DOE's Bronx Plan, which will boost salaries in hard-to-staff positions and "give teachers formal decision-making power in their schools" according to Chalkbeat.
Teachers threaten students with " i will make sure myself that you dont graduate " if given any disrespect. blackmail much ?

"Most of the teachers are very good at their jobs and make learning interesting," writes a student. "Problems are addressed quickly and it's a friendly atmosphere as everyone is on first name basis." This student complains that among many students, "anything foreign or unheard of is not directly accepted."
A 6th grader recalled her introduction to the school in the summer: "We had orientation--food, games--at the high school."

In a June 1, 2005, Newsday article, Ellen Yan reports on a pilot program from the Bronx-based Mothers on the Move which began at the Fannie Lou Hamer Middle School last month. As part of the program, principals and teachers will go in pairs to homes, once in the fall and again in the spring to make connections with families. Rachael Wilde, a teacher at Fannie Lou Hamer, states, "It's just to give us an opportunity to have a different kind of conversation."

The School of Science and Applies Learning is on the state education department’s list of failing schools but it doesn’t qualify for the city’s renewal program, which gives schools additional support. Read more here.

I had the opportunity to have a meeting with the principle of the school, and the regular teacher to expose and discuss all the issues mentioned above. This person was reported to the school district, and he is no longer part of the school system. I also had the opportunity to talk to the regular teacher, who has my respect as the rest of the teachers from CS300, the teacher show me the records of my child and the progress and  goals they have to reach towards the end of the year.

I find Ps 314 staff and security to be insensitive to students and parents that are not of Spanish or Africa decent. I feel that the School doesn't serve the Afro American population or parents in inclusive manner. Racism is ugly in all its forms and PS 314 is an example of what a PS shouldn't be.

Fairmont Neighborhood School incorporates neuroscience into their lesson plans in an effort to empower students living in poverty through giving them an understanding of how the brain grows and heals, nprEd reports.

This school is horrible. Don't go. I'm now in my senior year here, and the senior trip is horrible. They are going to send us to the 9/11 memorial, the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, and a dinner at Dave and Busters for 100 dollars for a senior trip. That has to be the worst senior trip ever, also with the new principal who used to be the assistant principal, the school is running out of money. Spanish class has been dropped, Music has been dropped for 8th grade, Health has been dropped, and we barely have any space. You carry a BUNCH of stuff every day for school, and get yelled at every morning when we line up in the gym before school stars. The assistant principal just yells at us for like ten minutes, and we have to do drills like army soldiers. The school probably isn't #1 in the District anymore, even if so District 12 is horrible, so it isn't hard to be #1 in it. The teachers have problems with fellow teachers, (which we have to call professors) and they occasionally talk bad about other teachers. ELA is the same thing every year in Kappa III, Science is alright, in Social Studies you learn the same thing every year. Math is complicated, and not explained well. Do NOT go to this school, you will regret it. The cafeteria is horrible as well, and it's crowded with 2 grades in the cafeteria, and we barely go outside because if a student does something wrong, everyone gets blamed for it. The motto is ''It's we not me in Kappa III.'' Unless you want to learn absolutely nothing and spend the most useless years of your life with a HORRIBLE senior trip, don't go here. We only have like 1 trip a year as well, and that's on the yellow school bus. The only good trip I recall was going to six flags but only our class got it because we won a competition. The teachers are also BLIND in this school and DEAF. Students cuss a lot behind the teachers backs (literally) and hit other students right in front of the teacher's eyes and get away from it. This school is HORRIBLE, and is BROKE, and you will hate it here. The people you meet here are really cool, but some of them are really annoying as well. The neighborhood is horrible, and is really poor. You will probably get chased a couple of times, and possibly jumped if you say the wrong thing. It's also very unfair in the school because people who skip class ALL THE TIME and who cheat in exams and projects always get the Gold Honor Roll (95% average or above) or the Silver or Bronze honor roll. It's really unfair, but since they cheat on everything they get a free pass through junior high school. The school is only 2% White, and 2% Asian. So if you're white or Asian prepare to get made fun of. If any one of your parents are middle class, you will have to pay for lunch, every day. There's no sports clubs in the school, besides nyjtl         (New York Junior Tennis League) which you have to stay until like 5:30 and you barely do any tennis, and they never win ANYTHING. The school is just a horrible experience, 80% of the teachers are useless, but some of the teachers are really good. I wouldn't recommend to go to this school, it's really bad, and we don't even have lockers. We don't even have desks to store our stuff in or anything. We have to carry a bunch of stuff in our bookbags, including our binders. It's horrible. There's no school plays, and you're never in the auditorium because it's shared by 4 DIFFERENT SCHOOLS! Don't apply for this school, it's very bad in my opinion. Classes keep getting dropped, no trips, horrible teachers, barely any space, bad after school programs, poor environment, and no extracurricular activities. I can't wait to graduate, even though the graduate is going to be horrible and the senior trip makes no sense. Who would want to go to the 9/11 memorial during their senior trip?
he is right.

KAPPA III is the #1 school in District 12.  In 2013-2014, the school received the highest scores, in district 12, for ELA and MATH State Exams.  In addition, KAPPA III also has the highest attendance record in the district.  Student are College & Career ready as the school provides opportunities for students and families to learn about an array of colleges and careers.  All students are provided an excellent college-preparatory education.  The believe is that all students will learn, achieve and become great leaders in and outside of their communities.  In 2013-2014, KAPPA III was the recipient of Respect For All Schools.  Teachers and staff work around the clock to ensure students develop knowledge and persevere.  KAPPA III believes in assertive discipline and foster a sense of loving community.  Positive Behavior Support Initiative is implemented to motivate students to succeed.  Overall, KAPPA III is a high-quality school and this is demonstrated by their high academic performance.  Every year, students are admitted to Specialized and Screened schools.

I WAS A STUDENT AT THIS SCHOOL AND HAVE  GRADUATED WITH AN AMAZING GRADE POINT AVERAGE . THIS SCHOOL HAS AMAZING ACADEMIC SKILLS AND WILL SURELY GO FAR. OUR TEACHERS ARE SUPPORTIVE AND CARE FOR WHAT WE MUST ACHIEVE. THE PRINCIPAL, THE STAFF AND TEACHERS PUSH US TO EXCEED AT OUR BEST:)

My daughter is currently in the 8th grade in this school. I must say I was of the opinion that this school was excellent, but that have since change after my kid being there 3 yrs. Firstly I must say that the Principal does her best however the staff is left to be considered. Ms. Matthews is a certified pig and this is not from hear say, this is from experience. The music program has been cut from some of the classes, music is vital. It was advocated in the schools directory that Latin was gonna be taught, up to this day the kids have yet to learn a foreign language. This year (2012-2013) the kids were told that they were gonna have a spanish class, they had one or two spanish classes no more and it was cut from the program, ridiculous. Information regarding activities in the school is sent home the day before giving parents no advance notice to  plan accordingly.  The school want the kids to do the Specialize HS Test, but has only started the classes 4 wks prior to the test giving only 2 classes per week and parents have to pay out of pocket. There is no summer school period for KAPPA III. The students are not polished and the teachers seem weary of them.  Prof. Joyce the Science teacher is a wonderful person, I observe him interacting with the kids outside of the classroom setting, just a wonderful man.  Overall I think parents should think twice about sending their child to this school. By the way my daughter is in the Regents class and in the top percentile in the school.

Acción Academy students will participate in an attendance and performance-improvement contest sponsored by Bronx native rap superstar Joseph Antonio "Fat Joe" Cartagena; the most improved class will win a new pair of Nike Air Jordans. Cartagena says he hopes the program will lead to further brand partnerships in the future, the Hunts Point Express reports.

Accion Academy is among 40 middle schools selected for an extension of the Middle School Quality Initiative, a program that increases professional development with Common Core-aligned literacy strategies and gives targeted funding for literacy training and materials. Sponsored by the New York City Council, Robin Hood, The After School Corporation, and Harvard Ed Labs, the Middle School Quality Initiative aims to help at risk students stay on track with their academic goals, as well as accelerate students' progress towards reaching the Common Core literacy standards. With this expansion, MSQI will be in 89 schools in the city. Read the press release here.

I would love to be able to speak and see Ms. Sharron Spann she was the best and now that I'm older im very grateful for her help as a kid!!!! She was Part of the reason I wanted to come to school!!! Please contact me at Naveda4_16@yahoo.com I would love to let her know how well I'm doing!!!

"New Principal, Adrian Manuel's record speaks for itself. In his first ever year as a Principal, Mr. Manuel excessed (let go of) 3 teachers only to replace them with brand new Teaching Fellows," writes a teacher. "He rated every member of the staff who expressed a desire to leave the school "unsatisfactory" and discontinued 3 members of staff from the Department of Education. By the end of the 2007-2008 school year, 10 staff members were either forced to or chose to leave ACCION Academy from among a staff of about 17. ACCION Academy is not an institution in which teachers feel supported by the administration. Young teachers at this school must worry about the security of their jobs at a school with such a high turn-over rate."

According to a June 3, 2008 New York Daily News article, "Using the table as canvas and mosaic, paint and paper, students illustrated the positives in their community - such as family and religion - and the negatives, such as drugs and violence [through an art program, Learning through an Expanded Arts Program (LEAP)]. '"We want to tell people to just make the best of life, be larger than life and change will happen,' said student artist Aminat Agunbiade, 13. [Principal Adrian Manual added:] 'Usually, we're talking to them about being social activists,' he said, "but with this project they had a chance to be hands-on."'

The advantages of a small school are not lost on the children. As one boy said, "I like it because it's small and you know everyone, especially the teachers. Even if one kid is left behind, they don't give up on you."
A student notes that, "There are hardly any fights because we're all friends. I think anyone who's kind of quiet or shy would like being in a small school like this."
"This school has the greatest teachers, that are willing to go above and beyond. They'll do anything," said Principal Melinda Dore.

4th grade math teacher, Stephanie Flete, is a recipient of the prestigious Big Apple award, which recognizes "exceptional success in instruction, impact on student learning, and overall contributions to school communities," as reported by Chalkbeat.

Urban Scholars has forged a partnership with East Side House Settlement through the school's "Renewal Program". Four East Side House staff work at the school to help boost attendance, family engagement and academic achievement. Read more here.
No third-grade students at Urban Scholars passed the 2014 state ELA exam. Read more here.

Urban Scholars Community School has been selected to participate in the Department of Education's Community Schools initiative, aimed at boosting attendance and achievement by bringing in community partners to provide support for students and families. Urban Scholars Community School's partner is East Side House, Inc. Read more about the program here and see the full list of schools, their community partners and their proposed services here.

Ninety-four low-performing schools are now called “Renewal Schools,”. They will receive increased funds designated for an hour of additional learning time, after-school and summer programs, and teacher training. The principals will also be under review. Read more here.
Bronx students and students in poor areas score well below their peers on standardized tests. View the report: Exam Results Show Bronx Schools Lag Behind.

The 06/14/07 Daily News notes the Bronx Little's success at improving math test scores, and Principal Gordon comments on how the school accomplished the improvement. "The school had the most improved fourth-grade scores in the city, rising from 36.8% to 92.9%. Gordon said that there has been a great emphasis on data and indivizualized teaching at the school, allowing teachers to tailor assignments to kids' needs."

Kindergarten teacher B. Jacobs writes: "In September, I will be starting my second year as the Kindergarten teacher at Bronx Little School and have found Mrs. Gordon to be very supportive and devoted to making Bronx Little School the best it can possibly be. The parents are concerned and involved [and] the staff (though going through some changes) works very hard."

One 4th grade student who has attended the school since Pre-K said, "I like the school and Ms. Gordon because she is nice and knows what's good for us students"

"It's still a good school" especially compared to other schools in the area, says a parent who is, nonetheless, unhappy with some of the changes at Bronx Little. She says academics are not as rigorous as she would like.

Lizzette Tavarez, a parent, writes: "My son entered this school with some challenges grasping the third grade material. He was formerly a student at a parochial school ands was failing terribly. He was tested at the local school region and it was determined that he did not have a learning disability. Anxious and nervous I searched for a new school within the public sector and found information about Bronx Little School. The most appealing was their small class size and "non-traditional" teaching methods. I am happy to report that two very successful years have gone by. On his first year he came within a few points from getting a level 4 on the city exams. My son's education has included cultural growth through the arts and music... I recommend this school... I feel very fortunate to have Bronx Little School as a part of my son's educational foundation."

Unfortunately, this school is not good fit for my kid. It's a decent school but I do feel that the environment and my kid has grown apart and I'm looking into other school options. I believe other parents will be thrilled to have their kids in this school since the school do have many decent teachers and the principal is outstanding. But I am going to listen to my kid because she mentioned certain things to me and I need her environment to be comfortable so she can learn. Like I said, I will be looking into other school options.
PS 3 Principal Katrina Beecher explains how the school is working to create a welcoming environment in pre-k classrooms, according to The Hechinger Report.
PS 3 will share a "recess coach" with four other elementary schools as part of a program teaching games and encouraging students to play respectfully. Read more here.

PS 3 was approved for a school-based Oral Health
Clinic, sponsored by The New York Foundling Hospital, starting in September, 2014, the school reports.

A parent looking for a pre-k program writes: I took a tour of PS 3. The school is lovely and cheerful, the kids seemed very engaged in their classrooms, and the teachers that I spoke with were dedicated to the school and their enthusiasm in the classroom was palpable. They have an outstanding commitment to the arts (everyone goes to art, music and drama once a week), there's a separate science lab (with two science teachers and a robotics club), and their library (and librarian) is wonderful. They don't have a gym teacher anymore because of budget cuts, but they're one of a limited number in NYC schools that participates in Play Works.

Our Times Press reports that Principal Kristina Beecher was not informed that the school would be losing its gifted & talented program. In 2013 there are no longer gifted classes in kindergarten and 1st grade. Read more: Highly touted Gifted & Talented program in Bed-Stuy has two grades cut.
Dental health clinics will open in eight Brooklyn schools next year, including PS 3: NYC Schools to offer oral health-care clinics.

PS 3 is THE BEST School in all of Brooklyn, Hands Down!!! I went here from 1991-1998 (Kindergarten-6th Grade), and I have got to say that this school is incredible! The teachers are cool, the staff and faculty are decent, they care about the students, the lunches are well-prepared and well-cooked, and everyone at the school is on their toes on everything and everybody.  As an Alumni of this school (graduated in 1998), I am proud to be a prospective student at this school and I would recommend this school to anyone who is looking to place their child(ren) in an elementary school.

PS 3 is one of twelve NYC schools that host the Playworks program, which provides an active, healthy recess and play throughout the day in low-income elementary schools. A recent study shows that the program reduces bullying, enhances feelings of safety at school, increases vigorous physical activity during recess, and provides more time for classroom teaching. The Gotham Gazette discusses the practice of falsifying addresses to get children into better public schools. Read more: For Parents Seeking School Choice, Boundaries Don't Apply.
Teachers try to prevent individual performance ratings from being released to the public. Listen to the report: Teachers Union Heads Back to Court Over Release of Ratings.

The Bedford Village School is featured in The Daily News as one of 29 NYC schools awarded a garden classrooms grant. Read the article: City awards grants to 29 schools to create or expand 'garden classrooms'.

After attending this school from Pre-K through 5th grade, my son graduated in June 2010. I am extremely pleased with the overall education that he received there. Upon his graduation he was invited to attend some of NYC's most renowned programs - Medgar Ever's Prep, Prep for Prep, private school De LaSalle Academy, Phillipa Schuyler M.S. And Mark Twain for the Gifted and Talented. 

Socially, he went from a shy and withdrawn student to one with an offbeat sense of humor that he loves to share. The friendships that he's made are continuing through phone calls, emails and visits. I thank the teachers that realized who he was inside and helped him bring it out. The various arts programs that P.S. 3 invite into the school as well as take the students to visit have added another dimension to him. Those experiences allow my son to fit comfortably into his new school's setting. Concerts and museums are second nature to him. Although I was sometimes uncomfortable with what appeared to a chaotic lunch or dismissal time, there was always an adult who could readily explained what was happening. 

My one complaint is the lack of parental involvement in this school.
thank you for saying that about writing about tamerra thompson lol

"I am a graduate of this school and it gave me a great foundation for the rest of my schooling," writes alumna Tamerra Thompson, who is now in college. "I was in the gifted program while I attended P.S. 3 and the teachers and administration made it feel like a tight-knit family where every child felt wanted, not like just another student."

A parent complains: "I'm not too happy with the new curriculum the school is teaching. I feel the children are not getting enough structured learning. Some of the teachers are not as academically strong as they could be. I'm waiting to see what the math scores will be this year. Hopefully the school chancellor will take note and do what's best for the children."

"PS 3 has been on top of things with my kids," a parent volunteer said. "Overall it's good. Some teachers I've seen could be stronger; there is a lack of control in some classrooms when teachers can't get kids to calm down." Kids "need a strong male figure," this father said.

"Ms. Beecher is fabulous," said a school social worker of the principal.
